item.title: UK union loses latest bid to push for workers' rights at Deliveroo - Reuters UK
item.description:
UK union loses latest bid to push for workers' rights at Deliveroo  Reuters UK

The High Court has rejected the latest attempt by a British trade union to push for workers' rights at food courier Deliveroo, in a case which is a rare example of gig economy firms successfully defending their business models. The Independent Workers Union of Great Britain (IWGB) wants to represent riders in the north London area of Camden, hoping to secure rights such as the minimum wage, which they are not currently entitled to, due to being classified as self-employed. Firms such as Uber [UBER.UL] in the gig economy - where many people work for multiple employers without fixed contracts...

item.title: Deliveroo riders not entitled to collective bargaining - Financial Times
item.description:
Deliveroo riders not entitled to collective bargaining  Financial Times

Deliveroo riders are not entitled to collective bargaining the High Court ruled on Wednesday in the latest legal case for the “gig” economy. The High Court dismissed a judicial review challenge brought by the Independent Workers Union of Great Britain, a trade union, which argued that it should be recognised by the food delivery company for the purposes of collective bargaining for its riders. The union claimed that not allowing collective bargaining breached the human rights of Deliveroo riders, under Article 11 of the European Convention on Human Rights. It brought the legal challenge aft...

item.title: Uber and Deliveroo talks ‘miles apart’ on valuation - Financial Times
item.description:
Uber and Deliveroo talks ‘miles apart’ on valuation  Financial Times

Uber’s attempt to buy Deliveroo has stalled because the two sides are “miles apart” on a valuation for the food delivery service, according to people briefed on the discussions. The ride hailing app is keen to buy or invest in Deliveroo, one of the UK’s biggest tech success stories, but a recent offer for the company valued it at less than $2bn while Deliveroo has pegged its value at $4bn, according to people briefed on the talks. It was reported in September that Uber had held early-stage talks to acquire or invest in the London-based start-up, as it expands its Uber Eats business. The two...

item.title: Uber/Deliveroo: take it away - Financial Times
item.description:
Uber/Deliveroo: take it away  Financial Times

If Uber cancels its order for London-based food delivery business Deliveroo it will not be because the US group has lost its appetite for takeaways. Home cooked meals are still falling out of fashion and Uber Eats is proving a good way to funnel new customers into the company’s wider ecosystem of services. Uber’s hesitation is more likely connected to Deliveroo’s $4bn pricetag. Deliveroo may be a well-funded local success story with about a fifth of the market and a higher average price point than Uber Eats, but the company’s hoped for valuation always sounded ambitious. Revenue at Delivero...

item.title: Europe’s On-Demand Economy Draws Complaints. And Regulators. - The New York Times
item.description:
Europe’s On-Demand Economy Draws Complaints. And Regulators.  The New York Times

As self-employed work forces and nontraditional work contracts proliferate, governments and courts are considering tougher protections.

item.title: Is Deliveroo an ‘Amazon’? - Financial Times
item.description:
Is Deliveroo an ‘Amazon’?  Financial Times

Amazon has a special place in the venture capital mythology. Jeff Bezos was criticised by tech sceptics during the dotcom bubble, but he proved them wrong and has built a corporate juggernaut, all while persuading investors to accept meagre or non-existent profits. The company is therefore the go-to response to criticism of loss-making startups: ‘They said the same about Bezos, and look what happened”. Last week, Deliveroo, the food-delivery startup, published its 2016 accounts, which revealed that the four-year-old business lost £129m. More importantly, revenues of £128.6m cost £127.5m to ...

item.title: Gig economy platform splits the jury - Financial Times
item.description:
Gig economy platform splits the jury  Financial Times

Readers will not find Deliveroo on the list of European digital champions this year. The London-based takeaway delivery service was considered for inclusion, thanks to an impressive growth rate — revenues more than doubled in 2017 — and a valuation of more than $2bn. Deliveroo has undoubtedly shaken up the fast-food sector. However, some judges were critical of its decision to treat delivery drivers as self-employed rather than workers, without rights to sick pay or minimum wage. Deliveroo is not the only one facing controversy. Digital transformation at an established company will often me...

item.title: Deliveroo drivers being denied basic human rights, High Court is told - The Independent
item.description:
Deliveroo drivers being denied basic human rights, High Court is told  The Independent

Deliveroo riders have been denied their human rights to collective bargaining, the High Court has heard in the latest legal case involving the so-called "gig economy". The Independent Workers Union of Great Britain (IWGB) is attempting to overturn a ruling which found that the company's riders are not entitled to collective bargaining rights because they are "self-employed". The union wants to represent Deliveroo riders in order to negotiate on issues of pay, hours and holiday with the company. Read more - Uber Eats and Deliveroo riders join McDonald's workers on strike - Deliveroo faces in...

item.title: Uber Eats plans to triple headcount in Europe - The Telegraph
item.description:
Uber Eats plans to triple headcount in Europe  The Telegraph

Uber has doubled down on its push into food delivery in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, tripling its headcount in the region and signalling the importance of the Uber Eats business as it prepares to float. Uber said it would have 900 people working in its Uber Eats business in the EMEA region next year, from 300 currently, having launched just two years ago in London. Uber Eats's EMEA head Rodrigo Arevalo said the company was also seeking to make it easier for people to order on its website, and not just on the app where it currently generates more than 80pc of orders. At rival JustEat,...

item.title: Data From Millions Of Smartphone Journeys Proves Cyclists Faster In Cities Than Cars And Motorbikes - Forbes
item.description:
Data From Millions Of Smartphone Journeys Proves Cyclists Faster In Cities Than Cars And Motorbikes  Forbes

Deliveroo rider speeding hot food to another hungry customer Smartphone data from riders and drivers schlepping meals for restaurant-to-home courier service Deliveroo shows that bicycles are faster than cars. In towns and cities, bicyclists are also often faster than motorized two-wheelers. Deliveroo works with 30,000 riders and drivers in 13 countries. That bicyclists are faster in cities will come as no surprise to bicycle advocates who have staged so-called “commuter races” for many years. However, these races – organized to highlight the swiftness of urban cycling – are usually staged i...

item.title: Restaurants fail for many reasons – don’t try to pin this on millennials - The Guardian
item.description:
Restaurants fail for many reasons – don’t try to pin this on millennials  The Guardian

Why are so many of Britain’s high-street restaurants closing? According to the Insolvency Service, the number of restaurant closures is up by a third this year. Some 1,123 restaurant companies have gone under since January. Mid-market chains have been the worst affected. This year Byron, Gaucho, Carluccio’s, Gourmet Burger Kitchen, and Jamie’s Italian have all entered administration or credit agreements, having tried to grow too quickly. Sir Terence Conran’s Prescott & Conran group is also in trouble. Some have blamed Brexit and millennials, the usual scapegoats. High rents and business rat...

item.title: Just Eat shares hot as investors dine on growth story, but is there a downside? - The Independent
item.description:
Just Eat shares hot as investors dine on growth story, but is there a downside?  The Independent

JustEat’s growth story is as hot as a Scotch Bonnet chilli. Its earnings, however, look more like the ice cream you’ll need on hand if you try to eat one raw. The latest trading statement made that clear. Revenues shot up 41 per cent, driven by impressive order growth just about wherever the company has planted its flag. It now expects the full year figure to come in at the top of the City’s forecast range. When it comes to the profits made on that, however, the reverse is true. Read more - Just Eat issues warning over threat from Deliveroo and Uber Eats - Just Eat listings include takeaway...

item.title: LavaGel Is Heating Up The $770bn Food Tech Industry - Forbes
item.description:
LavaGel Is Heating Up The $770bn Food Tech Industry  Forbes

MOSCOW – APR 23: Worker with Uber Eats bicycle and a bag in a street of Moscow on April 23. 2018 in Russia HºEATS is about to shake up the $770 billion foodservice industry thanks to its use of Lava Gel’s self-heating exothermic technology which, until now, has mostly been used for beauty and industrial applications. Currently, spot heat technology for the food industry provides a burst of heat and then fades out after 12-15 minutes (perfect for Military meals but not good for more extended periods). HºEATS products use Lava Gel because it can be formulated to reach 200° and stay hot for up...

item.title: Uber is going to triple its Uber Eats staff across Europe, Africa, and the Middle East - Fast Company
item.description:
Uber is going to triple its Uber Eats staff across Europe, Africa, and the Middle East  Fast Company

The company has said it plans to add an additional 600 Uber Eats staff across Europe, Africa, and the Middle East in an attempt to better take on rival food delivery services like Just Eat and Deliveroo, reports Bloomberg. A tripling of its staff would mean Uber employees 900 people relating to its Uber Eats division–up from 300 today. The Uber Eats division of Uber is becoming increasingly important to the company. Uber Eats currently represents over 10% of gross bookings for the company–a number expected to rise. But Uber Eats does not have the user base that other food delivery services ...

item.title: Just Eat warns delivery spending to take a bite out of earnings - Financial Times
item.description:
Just Eat warns delivery spending to take a bite out of earnings  Financial Times

Just Eat, the takeaway site, said investment in Latin American markets and its move into deliveries to rival Deliveroo and UberEats would take a bite out of earnings, despite full-year revenues that are likely to come in towards the top of management forecasts. Underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation would probably come in at the lower end of the board’s expected range of £165m to £185m, Just Eat said, “primarily reflecting investments in our dynamic LatAm markets in addition to our delivery initiatives”. Revenues meanwhile are expected to be towards the top ...

item.title: Just Eat: celery assault - Financial Times
item.description:
Just Eat: celery assault  Financial Times

For a balanced diet you must eat some celery with your kebab. Likewise, investors who turned their noses up at Just Eat’s move into UK meal delivery logistics should realise they will feel better for it in the long run. The tasty part of Just Eat’s offering is its digital ordering service that connects hungry households with nearly 90 per cent of the UK’s 34,000 independent restaurants — a legacy of Brits’ adoption of foreign cuisine. UK orders rose 16 per cent to £30m in the third quarter, 2 per cent above forecasts, according to an update. Demand for Indian and Chinese takeaways rose as t...

item.title: Just Eat hits back over Chancellor's digital tech tax - The Telegraph
item.description:
Just Eat hits back over Chancellor's digital tech tax  The Telegraph

Just Eat is expected to significantly ramp up its lobbying efforts in the coming months amid fears it will be among the British companies hardest hit by the Government's new digital services tax. Analysts at Credit Suisse said the food ordering service would likely be classified as a marketplace by the Treasury and so could be among those subject to the 2pc revenue tax announced by Philip Hammond yesterday. Only companies generating more than £500m in revenue globally will have to pay the tax, and "the only listed European internet business with revenues close to the threshold is Just Eat",...

item.title: Hundreds of ‘precarious workers’ march through London as Uber faces Court of Appeal - The Independent
item.description:
Hundreds of ‘precarious workers’ march through London as Uber faces Court of Appeal  The Independent

Hundreds of "precarious workers" marched through London as Uber faced the Court of Appeal in a landmark case over its drivers’ employment status and rights. The Independent Workers' Union of Great Britain (IWGB) organised the protest to offer “solidarity with Uber drivers and demand an end to all precarious work”. The union said that over 500 people including Uber drivers, fast food workers, Deliveroo couriers and outsourced cleaners joined the march from Transport for London headquarters in Blackfriars to the Royal Courts of Justice, less than a mile away. - Read more Uber Eats and Deliver...

item.title: How do Deliveroo and Uber workers cope with precarious pay? - The Guardian
item.description:
How do Deliveroo and Uber workers cope with precarious pay?  The Guardian

How do people cope when they don’t know how much they will earn from one month to the next? A report this week found that three-quarters of all workers do not receive the same pay packet from one month to the next – with the problem most acute for low-paid workers in the gig economy or on zero-hours contracts. The Resolution Foundation found that for those on the lowest annual incomes, the average monthly fluctuation in pay was £180 – which can make the difference between paying the rent or feeding the family. Many are forced to turn to crippling payday loans or high-cost credit cards to ma...

item.title: Tip Or No Tip? Deliveroo Riders Ripped-Off By Default - Forbes
item.description:
Tip Or No Tip? Deliveroo Riders Ripped-Off By Default  Forbes

Deliveroo. I’ve just started an assignment for a client in London. It’s too far to commute every day, so I had the choice between getting a city-pad or staying in a hotel during the week. There are pros and cons to each. For people who stay in the city only a handful of nights a week, there isn’t much to choose between the two options in cost – so the decision really boils down to convenience. To me, that really boils down to the choice between the benefits of a room-service menu for those evenings in with the laptop (such as tonight when I’m writing this article), or the benefit of not hav...

item.title: UK's Domino's shares rise on buyback, organic sales rise - Reuters UK
item.description:
UK's Domino's shares rise on buyback, organic sales rise  Reuters UK

Domino's Pizza Inc's (DPZ.N: Quote, Profile, Research) UK franchise Domino's Pizza Group (DOM.L: Quote, Profile, Research) launched a 25 million pound share buyback on Thursday after posting a 6 percent rise in organic sales due to a rise in website and app orders. Domino's shares rose as much as 8 percent after investors shrugged off comments that pointed to full-year pre-tax profit at the bottom of the company's previous guidance range. Much like its parent company, Domino's UK franchise has been focusing on sales through online channels to fend off competition from app-based services lik...

item.title: Are dark kitchens the satanic mills of our era? - The Guardian
item.description:
Are dark kitchens the satanic mills of our era?  The Guardian

They are known as “dark kitchens”: cramped boxes, usually plonked in city centres, in which cooks prepare meals that are ordered and sent out via food-delivery apps. Britain is reckoned to have at least 70, most of which are owned and run by the delivery giant Deliveroo under the brand name Deliveroo Editions. The food that comes out of them is sold in the name of established restaurants, and innocent customers might assume it somehow still comes from their high-street premises. But no: this is a new reality of “virtual branding”, in which all that sits behind this or that logo are the bare...

item.title: Deliveroo's sales rise to £277m but losses soar - The Guardian
item.description:
Deliveroo's sales rise to £277m but losses soar  The Guardian

Deliveroo’s sales have more than doubled to £277m, but losses at the takeaway delivery service also increased to nearly £185m. The privately owned company said losses went up by 43% after it invested £106m more last year than in 2016 in projects including a new head office in Cannon Street, central London, and opening Editions pop-up kitchens. Sales in Europe doubled, while other markets increased sales by 207% year on year. Deliveroo raised $500m (£382m) in extra funding in 2017, valuing the business at more than $2bn and making it one of a handful of UK-domiciled “unicorns”– as companies ...

item.title: Food ordering service Takeaway's German orders up 40 percent in third-quarter - Reuters UK
item.description:
Food ordering service Takeaway's German orders up 40 percent in third-quarter  Reuters UK

Takeaway.com, the European online restaurant ordering service, said on Wednesday its third-quarter orders grew by 40 percent in the German market, where it is locked in an expensive fight for dominance with Delivery Hero. Orders in Germany were 8.16 million, compared with 7.04 million a year earlier, the Dutch-based company said in a trading update. Takeaway is by far the largest food ordering service in the Netherlands, where it is profitable. Overall orders were up 31 percent to 22 million. Takeaway, which argues the online food ordering business will be highly profitable for just one pla...

item.title: Uber Eats feeds hopes for ‘Amazon of transportation’ - Financial Times
item.description:
Uber Eats feeds hopes for ‘Amazon of transportation’  Financial Times

For Uber, the route to new customers may be through their stomachs. Uber’s food delivery service is attracting an increasing share of customers who have never used the ride-hailing app, as the fast-growing unit expands beyond Uber’s core markets. Forty per cent of people now ordering food through the app are new to Uber, compared to a third earlier this year, Jason Droege, head of Uber Eats, told the Financial Times this week. In India, where Eats has launched in several cities, more than two-thirds of Uber Eats customers have never used another Uber service. When Uber Eats launched as a st...

item.title: Deliveroo losses swell as food delivery app invests in expansion - Financial Times
item.description:
Deliveroo losses swell as food delivery app invests in expansion  Financial Times

Deliveroo more than doubled its sales in 2017 ahead of a possible initial public offering, but losses at the food delivery start-up swelled as investment in global expansion saw it rack up another £100m in operating expenses. Global sales rose 116 per cent last year to £277m, the company said on Monday, while gross profits jumped from £1.1m in 2016 to £64.3m, driven by “growing maturity in existing markets, improved services and growing order volumes.” European sales rose 99 per cent compared to a rise of 207 per cent across other markets. But pre-tax losses widened to almost £185m, from £1...

item.title: Victoria calls inquiry into gig economy, including Uber Eats and Deliveroo - The Guardian
item.description:
Victoria calls inquiry into gig economy, including Uber Eats and Deliveroo  The Guardian

Victorian food delivery riders and those contracted to jobs online will be the focus of an inquiry following widespread claims of underpayment and poor treatment. The Victorian government has announced an investigation into the conditions of workers employed via digital platforms such as Uber Eats and Deliveroo. The inquiry will be chaired by former Fair Work ombudsman Natalie James. “Australia is crying out for an evidence-led, independent examination of the work arrangement in the gig and on-demand economies,” James said. Related: App delivery riders say they are paid as little as $6 an h...

item.title: Uber buyout talks with Deliveroo spark competition fears - The Telegraph
item.description:
Uber buyout talks with Deliveroo spark competition fears  The Telegraph

Uber would face close scrutiny from the UK's competition watchdogs if it seals a £1.5 deal for food delivery operator Deliveroo, City analysts warned last night. The Silicon Valley minicab giant is in talks with Deliveroo over a possible takeover of one of Britain’s most successful technology start-ups. Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at IG Group, warned that the combination could be delayed by a competition inquiry and said regulators would be likely to take a keen interest. Uber and Deliveroo both operate services that use couriers on pedal bikes, motorbikes or in cars to pick up fo...

item.title: Uber bid to buy Deliveroo hits shares in rival Just Eat - The Guardian
item.description:
Uber bid to buy Deliveroo hits shares in rival Just Eat  The Guardian

Shares in Just Eat have fallen 6% following reports that Uber is in talks to buy online food service rival Deliveroo for at least $2bn (£1.5bn). Investors in the takeaway app took fright at the prospect of Uber using Just Eat’s arch-rival as a UK platform for boosting the Uber Eats food delivery service. Just Eat shares hit a 2018 low of 664p on the news. “They say strength in numbers can be a powerful force and so it is no surprise that Just Eat’s shares have taken a big hit on speculation that Uber is going to buy Deliveroo,” said Russ Mould, investment director at stockbroker AJ Bell. “T...

item.title: The food app revolution will eat its drivers - Financial Times
item.description:
The food app revolution will eat its drivers  Financial Times

Wang Xing, co-founder of Meituan Dianping, aspires to “make life better for everyone”, says the prospectus for the world’s largest food delivery company, which floated this month in Hong Kong at a value of $53bn. That is an impossible dream, but his company is changing how millions eat. Uber’s on-demand taxi service used to be the ultimate disrupter, but rides for people are being challenged by delivery of food. Motorcycles and bikes speed around cities, carrying meals for millennials without the time or inclination to cook themselves. Uber hopes to grab more of an expanding market in Europ...

item.title: Uber 'in talks to buy Deliveroo' - The Telegraph
item.description:
Uber 'in talks to buy Deliveroo'  The Telegraph

Uber is in early talks to buy British food delivery startup Deliveroo, according to reports. The Californian ride-hailing giant is understood to have approached Deliveroo, understood to be worth around $2bn, sources familiar with the matter told Bloomberg. The sources, who wished to remain anonymous, claimed that Deliveroo founder and chairman would expect a figure higher than the company’s reported market value. Deliveroo is a popular app that sends couriers on pedal bike, motorbike or car to pick up food from restaurants that would not ordinarily offer delivery service. If Deliveroo foun...

item.title: Uber in talks to buy food delivery firm Deliveroo: Bloomberg - Reuters
item.description:
Uber in talks to buy food delivery firm Deliveroo: Bloomberg  Reuters

Ride-hailing company Uber Technologies Inc [UBER.UL] is in early talks to buy food delivery company Deliveroo, Bloomberg reported on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter. The value of the deal is not known, Bloomberg reported, adding that the offer would need to be considerably above Deliveroo's latest valuation. London-based Deliveroo was last year valued at more than $2 billion after raising $98 million from private investors. According to the Bloomberg report, the talks could fall apart because Deliveroo and its investors have been reluctant to relinquish independence. Delive...

item.title: Amazon made two moves for Deliveroo, one nine months ago: Telegraph - Reuters
item.description:
Amazon made two moves for Deliveroo, one nine months ago: Telegraph  Reuters

Amazon.com Inc (AMZN.O: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) made two preliminary approaches for British online food delivery company Deliveroo, the latest one about nine months ago, the Telegraph reported on Monday. The approaches were exploratory and have not progressed, the newspaper report said, citing an investor familiar with the matter. The first round took place two years ago. Amazon and Deliveroo were not immediately available for comment. Bloomberg, citing sources, reported last week that ride-hailing company Uber Technologies Inc [UBER.UL] is in early talks to buy Deliveroo. (Re...

item.title: Uber in early talks to acquire food delivery rival Deliveroo - Financial Times
item.description:
Uber in early talks to acquire food delivery rival Deliveroo  Financial Times

Uber is in early-stage talks to acquire the food-delivery app Deliveroo, according to people familiar with the matter, in the latest sign of its ambition to ramp up investment in the sector this year. The talks, first reported by Bloomberg, come amid intensifying competition in food delivery. Companies from Amazon and GrubHub to DoorDash and Just Eats are seeking to capture the loyalty of people who are more inclined to stay home than go out to a restaurant. Uber declined to comment. Deliveroo said “as a matter of policy we do not comment on rumour or speculation”. Uber claims to have built...

item.title: Deliveroo Tells Customer Thick Human Hairs In His Food Are 'Matter Of Personal Taste' - HuffPost UK
item.description:
Deliveroo Tells Customer Thick Human Hairs In His Food Are 'Matter Of Personal Taste'  HuffPost UK

A horrified Deliveroo customer who found two long human black hairs in his food was refused a refund – after the food app said the grim discovery was “a matter of personal taste.” Darren Wood, 31 was disgusted to find the hairs tucked into his bacon cheeseburger from Byron Burger, which was delivered by Deliveroo at 7pm on September 16. The insurance advisor from Norwich immediately complained to the food tech firm, but it refused to compensate him for the spoilt meal. A member of Deliveroo customer service team wrote: “I’m sorry to hear you weren’t happy with you order however I’m unable t...

item.title: Deliveroo to launch in Taiwan as Asia push continues - The Telegraph
item.description:
Deliveroo to launch in Taiwan as Asia push continues  The Telegraph

Deliveroo has pushed ahead with its expansion into Asia, unveiling plans to launch in Taiwan over the coming weeks. The British food delivery company will start services in the country's capital, Taipei, and then expects to roll out its app in other cities. Taiwan is the fourth Asia-Pacific market Deliveroo has entered, after Hong Kong, Singapore and Australia, and chief executive Will Shu said the move was a "personal milestone", given his parents were born in Taiwan and many of his family members still live in the country. "Taiwan is the market with my favourite food in the world. From a ...

item.title: Demand for online marketplaces growing 300pc each year, Stripe says - The Telegraph
item.description:
Demand for online marketplaces growing 300pc each year, Stripe says  The Telegraph

Spending on online marketplaces like Deliveroo, Booking.com and Airbnb is growing threefold each year as more Brits buy and sell products through internet bazaars. Internet and app shoppers are increasingly spending on digital marketplaces rather than on retailers directly, according to a report from payment provider Stripe. More than 70pc of Brits have turned to an online market like Amazon and ASOS while 20pc have used a food delivery app like Deliveroo. While Silicon Valley is often seen as ahead of the UK with its on-demand economy, the number of shoppers using apps for food delivery wa...

item.title: Foodora to pull out of Australia later this month - ABC News
item.description:
Foodora to pull out of Australia later this month  ABC News

By business reporter David Chau Food delivery company Foodora is pulling out of Australia, and will close its doors by August 20. In a statement, Foodora said the reason for its Australian closure was to "shift [its] focus towards other markets where the company currently sees a higher potential for growth". The company has been competing against rivals including Uber Eats and Deliveroo. Foodora said it would ensure that its employees, "support partners" and contractors found "suitable alternative roles". "I feel weird… this is nice news. It's like a dream come true," John Chessal, a Foodor...

item.title: MP calls on Deliveroo to guarantee riders the National Living Wage - The Telegraph
item.description:
MP calls on Deliveroo to guarantee riders the National Living Wage  The Telegraph

Food delivery start-up Deliveroo has rejected a suggestion from Labour MP Frank Field that its riders should receive the National Living Wage of £7.83 a hour. On Monday, Field published a report into the pay and job security of Deliveroo riders which recommended “a guaranteed minimum payment for riders who have made their services available to the company.” A guaranteed wage, Field wrote, would allow Deliveroo “to fulfil the level of service expected by consumers” and “would signal a much needed redistribution of risk between Deliveroo and individual riders.” Field made the suggestion based...

item.title: Deliveroo urged to pay national living wage as report finds workers paid as little as £2 per hour - The Independent
item.description:
Deliveroo urged to pay national living wage as report finds workers paid as little as £2 per hour  The Independent

Online food delivery company Deliveroo has been urged to make sure its riders are paid at least the National Living Wage (NLW) after a report found some are paid as little as £2 per hour. Labour’s Frank Field said that while the flexible “gig economy” model worked for some of its workers, there were others who required a more “stable” system with a higher hourly rate. The Birkenhead MP, who chairs the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, interviewed 179 Deliveroo riders for his report, which urges the firm to “guarantee” at least the NLW of £7.83 per hour “for all the time that people are l...
